messages.message:
Hi team, we still have many, many users registered on instabase.com (http://instabase.com) back to 2016 with gmail addresses registered etc.
From a data security & IP security perspective, what would be the best way for us to do an audit and deactivate / delete users who should no longer have access.

screenshot below is just a search for @gmail but there are likely many others.
I bet a lot of these are for our university programs

What scares me is if any of these people ever end up working for a competitor of Instabase they have the keys to our Ferrari. It also feels like a big cyber attack surface area of people who can access the platform as an authenticated user and we have no idea who they are.
Are any of these legitimate accounts? Who would know?

Other than Stanford students(??), i am not aware of any customers who should have access to Instabase.com (http://Instabase.com).... apart from when we have run training courses, which we should now create a training sandbox for.
The scale is so huge i would be tempted to give fair warning for anyone to raise objections and then deactivate all non @instabase.com accounts
It sounds like we need a thorough review of those who registered with a non-IB and non-edu email. We should probably disable a bunch that have been inactive for X years/months.

Many of these would be through the programs Jennifer Widom (the Stanford professor) runs outside of Stanford, and thus would not have .edu email addresses. I don't think we've ever told students in these courses (like Eugene's at Columbia) that they have to use .edu email addresses either. Going through and removing them all could be very disruptive. I like the idea of removing ones that haven't been used in X years.

How many users like this do we expect genuinely _*should*_ have access _*right now?*_ Given the risk surface area this exposes us to, i think we should consider communicating with Jennifer Widom, removing all non users from IB.com (http://IB.com) and isolating them in a separate EDU sandbox where we more tightly control off-boarding of users when they should no longer have access.

Imagine if just 1 of these users graduates and goes to work at Hyperscience, or Google Doc AI and realises they still have full access to our platform. Or if some of these are former interview candidates that did not take a job with us and end up at a competitor shortly after.

Thanks for the context @Jessica! I think it is better that we start taking this on sooner rather than later. A thorough execution plan will probably take some time to shape up I imagine, but I am with @Matt Weaver for the concerns that he have. The potential penalty we get for not managing these accounts properly does seem severe. @yj

As a side note, many (at least 77/5730 as of March 2021 Hackathon) of these accounts have easily-guessable passwords, and we suffer from some vulnerabilities that would allow an external actor to guess usernames unimpeded and then allow those non-admin accounts to do anything full site admins can do if they write some smart UDFs (explored in Fall 2020 hackathon and again in march 2021)

@Rakesh and I outlined some of our findings during hack week (https://docs.google.com/document/d/1ms5v3KnjRDo_TK9LfIsH8_2Ur8B6uSJ_S16G79i-dTg/edit#heading=h.whu4dr1anijg), and I’m happy to chat with anyone who’s curious to learn more!
